Pre-Game Insights: The Mets' early barrage in their 12-6 win in Game 5 forced the series back to Dodger Stadium for Game 6.
Freddie Freeman’s injured right ankle keeps him out of the Dodgers' starting lineup for Game 6.
Sean Manaea’s renaissance included a win at Dodger Stadium in Game 2.
The Mets deployed both Ryne Stanek and closer Edwin Díaz for multiple innings in Game 5.
The Dodgers will be in significantly better shape for Game 6 after Brent Honeywell spared the bulk of his bullpen by gobbling up 14 outs.
Game 6 will be played at Dodger Stadium on Sunday. First pitch is scheduled for 8:08 p.m. ET/5:08 p.m. PT on FS1.
Mets: LHP Sean Manaea (12-6, 3.47 in the regular season) will start.
Dodgers: RHP Michael Kopech (6-8, 3.46 in regular season) will start.
Mets' starting lineup includes Francisco Lindor, Brandon Nimmo, Mark Vientos, Pete Alonso, Jesse Winker, Starling Marte, Tyrone Taylor, Jeff McNeil, and Francisco Alvarez.
Dodgers' starting lineup includes Shohei Ohtani, Mookie Betts, Teoscar Hernández, Tommy Edman, Max Muncy, Kiké Hernández, Andy Pages, Will Smith, and Chris Taylor.
The Mets will lean on Manaea for as long as possible due to a shorthanded bullpen.
The Dodgers' high-leverage relievers Blake Treinen, Evan Phillips, and Michael Kopech will be available for multiple innings.
Jeff McNeil is fully healthy and capable of contributing despite his recent wrist fracture.
Brandon Nimmo is playing through plantar fasciitis in his left foot.
Freddie Freeman is held out of the starting lineup for Game 6 due to a badly sprained right ankle.
Miscellaneous Highlights: This is the fourth postseason meeting between the Mets and Dodgers, dating to a 1988 NLCS win for Los Angeles.
The Mets led Major League Baseball with a 67-40 record from May 30 through the end of the season.
The Dodgers ranked in MLB’s top five over that stretch with a 62-42 record.
In Game 5, the Mets became the first team since the 2022 Angels to avoid striking out in a postseason game.
